content: But even this alleged statistic appears to be false. Barfield was a gang investigator, and what he actually said was: "I have identified 320 soldiers as gang members from April 2002 to present." So we now have the Department of Homeland Security defaming our servicemen on the basis of a press release by a left-wing pressure group that misrepresented the principal empirical support for its claim. Nice. The Homeland Security report further supports its suspicion of returning veterans by referring to an FBI report released last year: The FBI noted in a 2008 report on the white supremacist movement that some returning military veterans from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have joined extremist groups. So, how many are "some"? You can read the FBI report, titled "White Supremacist Recruitment of Military Personnel since 9/11," here. Notwithstanding the deliberate vagueness of the Homeland Security document, the FBI was actually very specific: A review of FBI white supremacist extremist cases from October 2001 to May 2008 identified 203 individuals with confirmed or claimed military service active in the extremist movement at some time during the reporting period. This number is minuscule in comparison with the projected US veteran population of 23,816,000 as of 2 May 2008, or the 1,416,037 active duty military personnel as of 30 April 2008. ... According to FBI information, an estimated 19 veterans (approximately 9 percent of the 203) have verified or unverified service in the ongoing wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. There you have it: a whopping 19 actual or alleged veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan have joined the "extremist movement." (The FBI notes that some of these "may have inflated their resumes with fictional military experience to impress others within the movement.") It's hard to avoid the conclusion that this Homeland Security report is politically motivated, and reflects the authors' political prejudices more than an objective evaluation of a significant terrorist threat. In that context, the report's conclusion seems a bit ominous: From:+++http://www.powerlineblog.com/archives/2009/04/023329.php

Legion says their wrong, VFW says no harm. As for me and the soldiers I work with around here, we find it pretty damned insulting. Oh, you can be sure that I am a veteran. I wore the uniform proudly for 27 years, combined Active Army and Army Reserve. But since I was also a registered Democrat during that same 27 years (and continue to be), various Republican Presidential Administrations have considered me a danger to the nation (For example, I was put under surveillance during the Nixon-McGovern presidential election because I was supporting McGovern and therefore i was subversive - according to the parts of my FBI file I received under a Freedom of Information request). You know what? I "found it pretty damned insulting" that my patriotism was questioned because I was a registered Democrat, rather than a registered Republican. Just as I "find it pretty damned insulting" when certain people imply that I really am not an Army veteran because I am not a registered Republican and I support the present President of the United States. Actually, I suspect that much of these reports, which were commissioned by the Bush Adminstration and just recently made public, have a lot of truth in them. If I am serving with a white supremicist in my unit, I would like to know about it so that he or she could be watched carefully and dishonorably discharged if they violate the Constitution and or the UCMJ. I would not allow them to hide behind a "green wall of silence", like the "blue wall of silence" where an honest policeman covers for a dishonest policeman because "cops have to support fellow cops". Soliders shouldn't support fellow soldiers if they know that fellow soldier has broken the law or is planning to break the law. I have had both white and black supremicists assigned to my units in the Active Army and in the Army Reserve - and I have done what I could to get them out of the military. But back to my original comment to the OP: if you can cite someone not from a Rightist or Leftist blog or website to back up your position - then it merits honest discussion.

content: The political slant to this is a pile - the report was commissioned by the outgoing administration (which was decidedly Republican and right-wing if not definitively conservative) and was preceded by a similar report detailing left-wing groups. As to the soldiers, there are some valid points here. Considering the ideological make-up of the military, the change in "ruling party", and President Obama's race, I do not think it that far out to say that right-wing extremist groups will have an easier time recruiting from the military this year. I certainly have not seen anything that would make it harder. I am not saying 10% would join - probably more like 0.01% - but an increase seems likely. I do not think this is slanderous, as any group is likely to include at least 0.01% "bad eggs". Also, as an FBI agent or cop, who should I worry about (assuming both are in the extremist group) - the guy who weighs 300lb. and hunts from his truck, or the lean 180 fresh from the Afghanistan? Military personnel are in general more assertive, more directed, and already trained in a whole variety of destructive techniques - training that they can pass on to others. I do not read this report to say that Vets are overall any danger - it is just that when they go bad, they can cause a lot more damage.

According to FBI information, an estimated 19 veterans (approximately 9 percent of the 203) have verified or unverified service in the ongoing wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. There you have it: a whopping 19 actual or alleged veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan have joined the "extremist movement." (The FBI notes that some of these "may have inflated their resumes with fictional military experience to impress others within the movement.") It's hard to avoid the conclusion that this Homeland Security report is politically motivated, and reflects the authors' political prejudices more than an objective evaluation of a significant terrorist threat. In that context, the report's conclusion seems a bit ominous. Well said. The DHS obamanites are a far greater danger to America than our returning veterans.

content: quote: Originally posted by transport1: quote: Originally posted by Fightdirector: quote: Originally posted by threerings: From:+++http://www.powerlineblog.com/archives/2009/04/023329.php As Arte Johnson would say on "Rowan and Martin's Laugh-in": "Very interesting" I took the liberty of clicking on the URL you cited - and found it to be a Right-wing blog site operated by Newt "I have Christian values even though I've divorced two of my three wives because I wanted to marry my mistress at the time" Gingrich. If someone was to post something to these Forums citing the Daily Kos, Crooks and Liars or Media matters, it would automatically be discounted as being anti-American Leftist propaganda. Considering your cited source, shouldn't we automatically discount your quote as Anti-American Rightist propaganda? Well, that depends. Seeing as how you claim to be a vet, that would automatically make you a right wing semi-oriented terrorist suspect. At least according to the way these people are portraying you. Legion says their wrong, VFW says no harm. As for me and the soldiers I work with around here, we find it pretty damned insulting. Oh, you can be sure that I am a veteran. I wore the uniform proudly for 27 years, combined Active Army and Army Reserve. But since I was also a registered Democrat during that same 27 years (and continue to be), various Republican Presidential Administrations have considered me a danger to the nation (For example, I was put under surveillance during the Nixon-McGovern presidential election because I was supporting McGovern and therefore i was subversive - according to the parts of my FBI file I received under a Freedom of Information request). You know what? I "found it pretty damned insulting" that my patriotism was questioned because I was a registered Democrat, rather than a registered Republican. Just as I "find it pretty damned insulting" when certain people imply that I really am not an Army veteran because I am not a registered Republican and I support the present President of the United States. Actually, I suspect that much of these reports, which were commissioned by the Bush Adminstration and just recently made public, have a lot of truth in them. If I am serving with a white supremicist in my unit, I would like to know about it so that he or she could be watched carefully and dishonorably discharged if they violate the Constitution and or the UCMJ. I would not allow them to hide behind a "green wall of silence", like the "blue wall of silence" where an honest policeman covers for a dishonest policeman because "cops have to support fellow cops". Soliders shouldn't support fellow soldiers if they know that fellow soldier has broken the law or is planning to break the law. I have had both white and black supremicists assigned to my units in the Active Army and in the Army Reserve - and I have done what I could to get them out of the military. But back to my original comment to the OP: if you can cite someone not from a Rightist or Leftist blog or website to back up your position - then it merits honest discussion.

content: The political slant to this is a pile - the report was commissioned by the outgoing administration (which was decidedly Republican and right-wing if not definitively conservative) and was preceded by a similar report detailing left-wing groups. As to the soldiers, there are some valid points here. Considering the ideological make-up of the military, the change in "ruling party", and President Obama's race, I do not think it that far out to say that right-wing extremist groups will have an easier time recruiting from the military this year. I certainly have not seen anything that would make it harder. I am not saying 10% would join - probably more like 0.01% - but an increase seems likely. I do not think this is slanderous, as any group is likely to include at least 0.01% "bad eggs". Also, as an FBI agent or cop, who should I worry about (assuming both are in the extremist group) - the guy who weighs 300lb. and hunts from his truck, or the lean 180 fresh from the Afghanistan? Military personnel are in general more assertive, more directed, and already trained in a whole variety of destructive techniques - training that they can pass on to others. I do not read this report to say that Vets are overall any danger - it is just that when they go bad, they can cause a lot more damage.

content: quote: Originally posted by threerings: But even this alleged statistic appears to be false. Barfield was a gang investigator, and what he actually said was: "I have identified 320 soldiers as gang members from April 2002 to present." So we now have the Department of Homeland Security defaming our servicemen on the basis of a press release by a left-wing pressure group that misrepresented the principal empirical support for its claim. Nice. The Homeland Security report further supports its suspicion of returning veterans by referring to an FBI report released last year: The FBI noted in a 2008 report on the white supremacist movement that some returning military veterans from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan have joined extremist groups. So, how many are "some"? You can read the FBI report, titled "White Supremacist Recruitment of Military Personnel since 9/11," here. Notwithstanding the deliberate vagueness of the Homeland Security document, the FBI was actually very specific: A review of FBI white supremacist extremist cases from October 2001 to May 2008 identified 203 individuals with confirmed or claimed military service active in the extremist movement at some time during the reporting period. This number is minuscule in comparison with the projected US veteran population of 23,816,000 as of 2 May 2008, or the 1,416,037 active duty military personnel as of 30 April 2008. ... According to FBI information, an estimated 19 veterans (approximately 9 percent of the 203) have verified or unverified service in the ongoing wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. There you have it: a whopping 19 actual or alleged veterans of Iraq or Afghanistan have joined the "extremist movement." (The FBI notes that some of these "may have inflated their resumes with fictional military experience to impress others within the movement.") It's hard to avoid the conclusion that this Homeland Security report is politically motivated, and reflects the authors' political prejudices more than an objective evaluation of a significant terrorist threat. In that context, the report's conclusion seems a bit ominous. Well said. The DHS obamanites are a far greater danger to America than our returning veterans.
